channel.description:
So for my junior project we have to pick a social issue to research and create a powerpoint about, and while most of my friends are doing ocean pollution etc, they can just go on and on about how seaturtles are dieing because they think plastic bags are jellyfish. I cant.
Im doing gun control, and the reason I came here is because people from about every corner of the world are here and I need as MANY opinions and beliefs as I can get.
The rubric just for info - Significance of topic today - Effects on society (this is where you guys come in) - Personal (Friends/family) effects - Cited sources (if you use statistics or anything please post a link to the source)
For significance today I will most likely put the modern uses for guns, like law, hunting, self defense, sport shooting, and crime.
Effects are obviously death and innocent deaths, allows crazy people to shoot up malls and stuff
etc
So Ill start the thread off with a question and hopefully it grows
Why shouldn't the public be allowed to have easy access to guns?
Why should they?

In the UK, based on these numbers, there was one knife crime commited for every 374 people (rounded down).

[ul][li]Heavy, guns carry weight, granny’s are fragile and weak. some guns are VERY light, I carry a Ruger LCR .38 Special, weighs in at 13 ounces[/li]
[li]Recoil, granny’s going to miss and knock her self out. No again, many don’t have any recoil at all (.22, .25 Auto), and even a .38 Special isn’t that bad[/li]
[li]Reactions, granny has none. So throw her to the dogs? Obviously she has enough to defend herself.[/li]
[li]Safety catch, granny’s need showing how to use EVERYTHING. What safety catch? Most guns have safeties built into the triggers, and are quite literally point and click. The ones that DO have safeties have a button or lever, you think she can’t click a button or lever?[/li]
[li]Death, granny will die in a gunfight. Why can’t she be a better shot?[/li][/ul]

http://www.kcci.com/news/23208133/detail.html

morningjournal.com

LORAIN -- Nearly 200,000 Ohioans have been issued a license to carry a concealed handgun since the state's concealed carry law took effect in April 2004.

If that’s only one moment in a lifetime, I want to be prepared. I have car insurance, but that doesn’t mean I want to be in a crash. It just means being prepared.

You will want to write about Kennesaw, Georgia, USA, where they had many home burglaries until they passed a law requiring every home with adults that could legally own a gun to keep one in their home at all times. Crime disappeared. Criminals don’t want to die either.

Also look at how crime has fell drastically in EVERY state that has implemented a good concealed carry law since 1987, while crime has steadily risen in other states (Illinois being the most glaring example)

item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Some facts: The US is #46 on the list Bowser jr linked to, the one with weapons per million citizens, and the Netherlands is #47. So the Netherlands would make a good candidate to compare the US with.

The Netherlands is also one place behind the US when it comes to total crimes per capita. But when you look at homicides with firearms, the US is listed #7, and the Netherlands isn’t even on the list (which includes 32 countries). Murders with firearms: US is #8, and the Netherlands is not on the list (of 32). Murders per capita (all murders): US #24, the Netherlands #51.

Before I drown you with facts (I hope they are based on real numbers, and not pulled out of someones arse), I’ll give my first opinion/assumption/whatever: Although the Dutch have almost as many guns as the Americans have, they don’t seem to use them against other human beings. The reason: we’re only allowed to own guns with a permit (I’ll look into the requirements later), and when we own a gun, we’re only allowed to use them on a shooting range. When transporting the gun, we have to disassemble it, and keep it in a briefcase. We also have to store our guns in a safe. If we don’t, and the gun is used in a crime, we’re responsible too.

So that’s one way too look at it. An other way to look at the differences is that although guns are used to kill people in the Netherlands, it mostly happens in the circles of organized crime. There are some murders not related to organized crime, but most are.

I can also bring up the argument that in the Netherlands, the social welfare is better than in the US. I can’t show any numbers proving this argument, but I have a strong feeling it helps.
